Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Wearable Medical Device for Menopause Management
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project (NSF Lineage: Award Number 1644664) is borne from the development of a customizable symptom management tool to support women experiencing menopause. The negative perception of menopause causes symptom embarrassment which leads to deficiencies in health literacy and inefficient symptom management. This project's technology, a wearable-app system, addresses this inefficiency by providing the means to inform and support women throughout menopause. The proposed I-Corps program explores commercialization opportunities within the project's initial application focus of menopause symptom management and also investigates the potential of applications in the cancer symptom management and data sales markets. With respect to the latter, the prospective technology will gather an abundance of data that may be used to streamline biotechnology and pharmaceutical product development. Through adoption of this technology, women will be able to better communicate their symptoms to a more aware and understanding society. This opens the door to future innovations in additional areas of healthcare that are traditionally not openly discussed.

This I-Corps project is based on the premise that leveraging personal mobile devices and user data may create disruptive innovation in the healthcare space. The project's technology utilizes multiple sensors to collect personalized data which is used to provide the user with multiple ways to optimize management of her menopause symptoms, with the goal of minimizing their negative impact on her daily routine. Progress on the project to date includes development of an alpha prototype that has been used to test the feasibility of both hardware and software components. Current areas of focus include optimization of the physical design and data acquisition capability. The I-Corps process will allow us to improve our understanding of our customers? unmet needs and the ability of our technology to address them. This will guide the development of our technology, including optimization for manufacturing and feature enhancement, to address needs found in customer discovery and accelerate introduction of a useful product to market.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: CUNY City College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION OF THE CITY UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

POR.DRECONTENT:
Throughout the course of this project, we conducted more than 200 recorded customer discovery interviews, attended 5 conferences and trade shows, and hosted an event for customer discovery purposes.

At the start of this project, our main focus was to speak with women regarding their experiences related to menopause. We sought to identify their pain points and assess if our current technology, a skin moisture and temperature sensing wearable device, would meet their needs. Additionally, we focused on expanding our understanding of the ecosystem surrounding the menopausal experience. We spoke with gynecologists and other health care providers that treat women going through menopause, to gain insight into their role in how women choose to address their symptoms. We determined that education and community are two major areas of need for women going through menopause. Over the course of our interviews with menopausal and post-menopausal women, many expressed feelings of confusion, isolation, and a general lack of knowledge regarding this stage in their life. Our interviews with healthcare providers indicated that naturopathic and holistic providers are more likely to recommend symptom tracking behavior to their patients than are gynecologists and primary care physicians.

We used our initial findings to develop a web platform for menopausal women, with the goals of providing educational information and access to a supportive community. After determining that menopausal women would be our end user for a software-based solution, we shifted our focus to identifying markets for the initial technology we brought to this project. The information that we gathered from interviews with menopausal women regarding their use of health-related technology indicated that a majority were not currently using mobile applications and wearables. Therefore, we decided to explore the opportunity to update the business model for our wearable device from direct to consumer to business to business. We re-focused our customer discovery accordingly.

We conducted interviews with individuals in scientific and business positions to better understand how organizations partner with startups, along with critical value propositions in the fields of clinical and academic research, digital health, pharmaceuticals, and data science. To do so, we attended a digital health conference and engaged in interviews with executives from research and health-related companies. Based on our findings, we created a new business model canvas with tested customer segments, new channels, and distribution options. This pivot provided us with the opportunity to identify and evaluate specific value propositions for our new customer segments. For example, pharmaceutical industry executives identified one potential value of our device as its ability to validate current therapeutics in their development pipelines. In addition, digital health founders are interested in expanding their market reach and, to that end, would like to incorporate technologies like ours into their existing platforms. We also learned that clinical research coordinators and scientific researchers value time efficiency from FDA approved research tools. 

The information that we gathered throughout the course of this project provides an important foundation for the further development of solutions for women entering and experiencing menopause. The identification of education and community as major areas of need, along with the information obtained regarding their current usage of health technology, will help to ensure that solutions properly address the actual pain points of menopausal women with greater scope and impact. We also identified a potential gap related to how doctors communicate with women regarding management of their menopause. The research conducted during this time allowed our team to identify unmet needs within the menopausal population and create a technology to address those needs. We then looked for new applications of the device we originally brought to this project. We also explored customer needs in various business settings to understand the potential of adopting technology to advance health research.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2020
Modified by: Jeffrey S Garanich
